captions.text:
Suppose you have a ball covered entirely with
hair and you're trying to comb the hair so

that it lies flat everywhere along the surface.
If the ball were a donut, or it existed in

two dimensions, this would be easy! But in
three dimensions? Well, you're going to run

into trouble. A lot of trouble. A big hairy
ball of trouble.

That's because of a theorem in algebraic topology
called the "Hairy Ball Theorem" (and yes,

that's it's real name) which unequivocally
proves that at some point, the hair must stick

up. Now don't go wasting your time playing
around with a hairy ball trying to prove the

theorem wrong - this is math we're talking
about. It's proven - done - QED!

Technically speaking, what the Hairy Ball
theorem says is that a continuous vector field

tangent to a sphere must have at least one
point where the vector is zero.

So what does this have to do with reality
apart from uncombable hairy balls? Well, the

velocity of wind along the surface of the
earth is a vector field, so the Hairy Ball

Theorem guarantees that there's always at
least one point on earth where the wind isn't

And it doesn't really matter that the object
in question is ball-shaped. As long as it

can be smoothly deformed into a ball without
cutting or sewing edges together, the theorem

still holds. So the next time a mathematician
gives you trouble, ask them if they can comb

comments.author: azrael300s

comments.text:
If you had listened to the entire video, you would've seen that they did go 
into more detail. The mathematical definition states the theorem only 
applies to a "continuous vector field tangent to a sphere" (i.e a ball 
completely coated in hair). The "hairy ball" model was never meant to be 
the end all be all for the mathematical theorem, and you shouldn't expect 
that any model can substitute a formal explanation.

comments.author: JakeFace0

comments.text:
Actually, you know what. YOUR definition is still exactly the manner in 
which I used it.
You're right, 1+1 does not imply 2 because 1+1=2 is not an implication, 
it's an equality.
An implication would be something like 1+1=2 IMPLIES 2-1=1. Given the rules 
of the group of the integers under addition, we can deduce that 1+1=2 
"strongly suggest[s] the truth" of 2-1=1 even though 2-1=1 is "not 
expressly stated".
Implication, even in the colloquial sense is not a wishy-washy, vague 
suggestion. It's a strong suggestion in the lack of an express statement to 
a claim's validity. It is a "strong suggestion" and the mathematical 
definition is only slightly stricter.
As to the assumption that I looked at a picture and just couldn't fathom 
how those two poles could become one: some of my friends did a topology 
course this semester (a course which I will be undergoing in second 
semester too) and I had discussed the hairy ball theorem and simply 
mis-remembered the statement of the theorem.
Also, why in the hell would you think that when I'm asking a question as to 
the nature of a theorem, that I would use anything other than the rigid, 
mathematical definition of the word "implies"?? And then when I said "chain 
of implication" you didn't pick up on the fact that the rigid definition is 
what I meant?
Also for someone who seems to have wanted to formally and rigidly lay out a 
series of statements, you seem to have neglected that the phrase "two 
points on a sphere" is not a claim and has no true or false value. Maybe 
what you meant to say was "a continuous vector field tangent to a sphere 
must have two points at which the field is equal to zero". That's a claim. 
That can have a true or false answer (namely: false). But when you 
construct a formal argument with two explicitly contradictory statements 
for the sole purpose of gloating over a point, you don't sound like a 
genius, you sound like and asshole.
comments.author: JakeFace0

comments.text:
The definition that has no bearing here?  Yes I'm familiar.
Your original question was written in plain English not as mathematical 
formula.... But you know thanks for playing the "I learned a new word and 
tried to look smart game" but please enlighten me as to how it applies 
here. 
If you want to use a logical connective then you need two statements.  Your 
original question 
"The hairy ball theorem" implies "...two points on the sphere"
Fails that; if you had written 
If the hairy ball theorem is true then that implies... two points on a 
sphere
In which case I could answer FALSE
Because
"Hairball theorm is true" = true
"Two points of a sphere" =  false
true->false = false
But that is well beyond what you were thinking; you simply looked at the 
picture drawn, saw two poles, and didn't see an easy way to eliminate one. 
 Stop playing games.
comments.author: Matthew Findley

comments.text:
That's the dictionary definition. Do you know the definition in formal 
logic?
comments.author: JakeFace0

comments.text:
you want to argue over the definition of imply?
"strongly suggest the truth or existence of (something not expressly 
stated)."

1+1 does not imply 2 it IS 2
Q.E.D.
comments.author: Matthew Findley

comments.text:
When you perform a proof you prove an implication.
you prove that a^2+b^2=c^2 IMPLIES c=+/- sqrt(a^2+b^2)

I don't think you quite understand the rigid definition of "imply".
comments.author: JakeFace0

comments.text:
+JakeFace0
Mathematical |proofs| are not all about following chains of implication 
they are all about following chains of proof.
a^2+b^2=c^2
is the same as
sqrt(a^2+b^2)=c not because it's implied but because it's proven
Similarly a^n+b^n=c^n where n>2 stayed unproven for 400 years.  Even though 
everyone knew it was probably true people still worked it; because in math 
it's never implied it has to be proven.
comments.author: Matthew Findley

comments.text:
Whilst your disagreement with my statement is well-founded and correct, 
your contention that "math never implies" is incorrect. Mathematical proofs 
are all about following chains of implication. Logic is built on this.

comments.author: Infiltrator2003

comments.text:
This explanation is so ambiguous. I mean.... how many hairs does the hairy 
ball have? My schtick is this: if there is only one hair... no problemo. 
Bend it down and it's fine. If there are 10 hairs on a relatively large 
ball, they should all go down just like the one did. Does the length of 
hairs even come into play? (and if not, why even make the analogy of a 
hairy ball?) How far does the analogy go? I'm guessing it has to do with 
going to infinity # of hairs given the context, but why can't countless 
amounts of hairs be gelled down just like all the other hairs? I don't get 
it. Gel can solve all of that, right? ﻿

Isn't it about the space the hairs cover, not the cuantity? I mean, you 
could have a 10-hair hairball as long as they cover all the surface of the 
ball. So, you cant have all the hairs follow the same vector. Like, if you 
try to run around the earth in a single direction, there will be places 
you'll never visit.

comments.text:
A ball being hairy implies that it has more that 1 or even 10 hairs. You

understand and I think it did a pretty good job of that.
